author: sebastiengllmt
title: cip25 (NFT) Rust & WASM library
description: CIP25, the NFT standard for Cardano, currently does not have an open source Rust, WASM or Typescript library to parse the on-chain metadata. Instead, users simply use a JSON representation of its data

f6_assessments.q0: Cardano needs to spread its wings – through decentralization of all its key components, decentralization of its governance system, decentralization of its platforms and community. Essentially, this is a proposal that will contribute to the decentralization of the Cardano code base through the implementation of an open source Rust, WASM and Typescript library for the Cardano Improvement Proposal (better known as CIP) no. 25. The team intends to use create this native new library from the Concise Binary Object Representation (CBOR) given in CIP25. This will help the developer community working with NFTs by providing an open source library in a new language - as CIP25 is the NFT standard for Cardano’s nonfungible tokens.
f6_assessments.q1: The dcSpark team is a group of very knowledgeable Cardano developers who have set up their company after leaving one of the three original focal points that created Cardano – the Emurgo arm that was responsible for building the light-weight non-full node wallet Yoroi. The author of this proposal is Sebastien Guillemot – if I may say so – one of Cardano’s high profile names in the developer community. Seb and his team really do not need a lot of introduction, if you have been following Cardano as closely as I have for the past five years or so. To cut a long story short, this time has what it takes to take this proposal and run with it to its natural conclusion. The modest budget of $7,000 corresponds in my view to the scope of the proposal and although a budget breakdown has not been provided – aside from a general statement that the funds will be used to finalize the project – for a team of this competence and a budget this small, this is satisfactory. I would commend the team for including a breakdown of the key milestones that will be checkboxed in order to realize this proposal. The GitHub links to the dcSpark code repo have been provided.
f6_assessments.q2: This is a relatively small-scale proposal for the dcSpark developer team and as they have public repositories for their open-source code it will be relatively easy to follow the code’s development through the provided links. dcSpark has public social media channels and the team could have committed explicitly to post updates through these channels. The auditability section of the proposal is a bit bare bones to be frank, yet we need to remember that Seb is one of the Catalyst funded editors of CIPs AND an active member in the discussions that are revolving in the Cardano improvement Proposal forum – hence there are multiple levels of auditability that do exist (social media channels, open source code on GitHub, final delivery of the product) – but the proposal as is written leaves scopes for improvement in the Auditability section. I would commend the team on their very clear presentation of the problem and offering a useful and practical solution to facilitate the writing of dev tools in Rust, WASM-compatible languages and Typescript that need to consume the CIP25 standard

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, parsing to and from the CIP25 metadata standard is useful to ensure the correct standard is used at all times.  It ensures the metadata on NFT is always encoded correctly. This will help create an awesome experience for developers on Cardano and avoid developers having to write their own parcers for individual projects.  I am a heavy user of the cardano-serialization-lib that is written by the same team and find it very useful. The deliverable scales well as it would be open source and available for anyone to use. This is a one-off deliverable, and they don't plan to come back for additional funding.
f6_assessments.q1: Yes, the proposers are well known in the Cardano community and have a track record of delivering useful tools. No links to social media accounts are provided. Their Catalyst proposals also tend to be minimalistic which doesn't set a great example for the rest of the proposers. I would suggest the proposers to use their position to set the standard in Catalyst. The solution is outlined in some detail and an example of the technique to be used is provided in a GitHub repo. The plan is outlined in 5 bullet points and a budget of $7,000 is set. It isn’t clear how the budget was derived as there is no meaningful links between the plan and the budget. They highlight a risk that some projects might have implemented the CIP25 standard incorrectly, and therefore some projects might get errors when parsing with their library. They suggest future work will be required to address this. Overall, I think the team has the necessary skill set to deliver this project; however a lot of the details around the budget and timelines is missing.
f6_assessments.q2: A roadmap with milestones is provided; however no time horizons and given. The KPIs are the same as milestones and success is stated very generically as having integrated with all the tools. There's also no meaningful explanation of how the budget is derived. The lack of key information makes it difficult to audit the project effectively, especially in terms of timelines and measurement of success.

f6_assessments.q0:
The project aims to create a Rust, WASM and Typescript library for CIP25, which is the standard specifying how NFTs are minted on Cardano.

To date, there are more than 6000 NFT projects* released on our blockchain and this makes it clear that there is a very high demand to support the developers in this sector with high-quality tools and libraries. Given their previous work I am confident that the dcSpark team will deliver a very useful support structure to NFT developers.
* source: https://opencnft.io/ 

This will be a very meaningful addition for the entire NFT ecosystem on Cardano and as such the project fits very well within the scope of the Developer Ecosystem challenge.

To further add to the potential impact of this proposal overall, the project is helmed by Sebastien Guillemot and the dcSpark team, very high-profile contributors in the developer ecosystem of Cardano, as such the outputs of the library this proposal is seeking to fund, are almost guaranteed to be impactful as they will reach a large audience right out of the gate. This in turn will guarantee that the library will gain adoption.

My qualification for making this assessment comes from the fact that I have been actively involved in the Cardano NFT ecosystem since February 2021 (before we actually had the capabilities to mint NFTs on Cardano). During this time I have worked together with developers in the NFT ecosystem on multiple projects.
f6_assessments.q1:
Even though the proposal is lacking in certain key areas of its feasibility presentation the dcSpark team has constantly delivered very high quality tools and products on Cardano, and I have no reason to believe that this project will be any different, as a consequence I think that there is a very high level of assurance that this project will be delivered according to the specifications presented in the proposal.

The requested budget is very sensible, modest even, and I see it as a further reflection of the commitment this team has towards the betterment of our blockchain.

As a proposer assessor, I would have liked to see a lot more elements presented, such as a clearly broken down budget or a more detailed description of the team, but I will exercise my judgement in assessing that, even though, the proposal itself is missing details about it’s implementation I am very confident that the dcSpark team will deliver on the scope of the project if funded.

One area where I wish the team would have been more diligent, is in describing the exact commitment required by all the projects they are working on that have been funded by Project Catalyst plus the ones they have submitted in Fund 9, and based on that present a plan on how they plan to manage the workload. These are elements that are requested by the new questions on the submission form. The information itself is very easy to get to however, simply by looking at their page on the Catalyst data aggregator website, Lido Nation,  https://www.lidonation.com/en/project-catalyst/group/dcspark , we can see that the company is currently working on 37 projects funded by Catalyst and have submitted 15 more proposals in total, across multiple challenges of Fund 9. But given the fact that dcSpark, the company now has over 40 employees it is very feasible that they will manage to handle the workload or hire additional people to meet the demand as from what I know they have other sources of funding outside of Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q2:
The auditability of this proposal is somewhat unique among the projects requesting Catalyst funds, because unlike many other smaller teams who are maybe relatively unknown in the Cardano community, dcSpark, the team behind this project is a high-profile entity in the ecosystem of our blockchain. As such the output of their work will be inspected by many other developers. This is especially true for this library related to NFTs (CIP25), which will not only be browsed by many developers, but actually used by most on a regular basis. Even more so given the fact that NFT projects constitute by far the largest number of projects on Cardano, according to data released by IOG. Because of this, it is very likely that the deliverables of this proposal will end up being some of the most checked outputs of any project funded by Catalyst.

That is why my rating for auditability is higher than it would have been had I judged the proposal solely on what is presented in it, as it is lacking a clear outline of KPIs and milestones, and the definitions of success are very minimal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal wants to build an open source library to parse on-chain metadata according to the Cardano Improvement Proposal 25 (CIP25). This will be implemented as native libraries for Rust, WASM and Typescript. 
This proposal aligns very well with the “Developer Ecosystem”-challenge and it is clear that it will add value by implementing a library for a CIP. The problem today is that data is represented in simple JSON formats but this implementation of libraries for CIP25 will bring structure and standardization to the ecosystem. This kind of standardization will help developers focus on building great solutions that tackle problems instead of spending lots of time on data management and/or integration. 
The proposers acknowledge that there is a possibility of future work in order to keep the libraries up to date and compatible, but it is estimated to be minor work and no further funding should be needed. All in all, the proposal is not very complex and the cost is low. Given the great alignment with the challenge setting and low risk profile of the proposal, it will receive 5 points in terms of impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposing team is credible with experience and a history of previous work done in the ecosystem. The github handles to two team members are provided to further back up their credibility and verify that they have the relevant skills needed to build the libraries. 
However, it is the proposal that is being assessed and ideally it could be improved to give the voters more confidence when voting for this proposal.
A good and sufficient plan/milestones given the scope are outlined but no timetable or estimates are given, this should be added. In its current state, it is unclear if the project will be finalized in a week or a year after funding.

Further, the budget states that all funds (7000 USD) will be used to develop the solution. This is not detailed enough, a good start to justify you claim of 7000 USD would be to list what work that needs to be done, estimate the work in hours and then multiply these hours with your hourly rate. This would give voters more confidence that your funding is honest.

The team is working on other proposals in this fund, these could be provided to increase the transparency for voters. Also, funded and implemented projects from previous proposals could be added to further increase credibility and transparency. They can prove as a “badge of honor” and it makes it easier for the community to quickly review your previous work and achievements. 

To summarize, the team is very credible and the chances of a successful implementation if funded is high. But objectively speaking, the proposal lacks the above mentioned details. A suggestion is to include these details in upcoming funds/proposals. For now, the score in terms of feasibility will be 3 points.
f6_assessments.q2:
The auditability section is lacking fundamental details needed in order to audit the project. The most crucial thing lacking are milestones with identifiable measures of success.
This could be solved by providing a simple roadmap with clear time estimates. 

It is not possible to measure success clearly, it can be done by comparing progress to the detailed plan but it is not easy for the average community member or voter to do. 
A suggestion is to include at least 2-3 KPIs that can be used to measure the success of the project as well as provide a definition of done that is clear and measurable.

In order for the community to audit the project, it would be preferable to have a clearly stated channel or forum where you deliver the updates of progress. It is unclear if this will be done in any of the github repos/profiles linked, or if any updates will be provided at all. Since it is an open source solution being built, transparency is key and this should be clearly stated. 

All in all, the proposal is rather poor in terms of auditability and could be improved by providing the details discussed above. The score given will be 2 points.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is another proposal from dcSpark, the company behind Milkomeda, Flint wallet and many more tools on Cardano. They are now asking for funds to build a Rust library to help parse on-chain data.
Currently, all the projects which need to parse CIP25 (Cardano standard) on-chain data, need to do so with ad-hoc implementations. The impact of this proposal will be to standardize the approach to this feature, which will help people build apps faster and in a safer manner.
As risks, the proposers identified the fact that some projects that have already made ad-hoc implementations might not be capable of integrating with the one proposed here easily, so further work might be needed in the future to support them.
I fully agree that this proposal effectively addresses the Developer Ecosystem challenge. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q1: For feasibility, we do not have a timeline, a roadmap, or even milestones, which is not ideal. Please consider providing a detailed timeframe in future proposals. We do, however, have a step by step approach to solving the issue and the team who will be working on the proposal are part of the company, meaning they have all the necessary knowledge and skills to fulfill the task. Furthermore, the required amount of funds is very low at 7000 USD, so considering dcSpark’s track record, I think it is likely this proposal will be implemented successfully. Score: 4.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability section is very sparse as well. The community is informed that progress means achieving each step in the detailed plan, which is possible to do, by checking the provided github links. Please consider, however, adding clear measures of success in the future (meaning with numeric targets). For example, X projects using the library within 3 months of completion. Otherwise, the community can only speculate whether the proposal yielded the desired return on investment. Score: 4.

f6_assessments.q0: This native library in Rust, WASM, and TypeScript will improve developer experience in Cardano. Better developer experience translates to better user experience, as well as faster and smoother deployment of product and features in Cardano dApps. Current ad-hoc parsing CIP-25 limits the indexing and can lead to hidden mistakes/bugs on CBOR parsing. The library created by this proposal can be used by many Cardano projects. I believe we have no excuse to not fund this proposal since most of our members surely hate delays, bugs, and the worst, error in their transactions or while using Cardano dApps. I also need to mention that most of projects and on-chain transactions in Cardano blockchain are currently NFT-related and therefore this proposal is a no-brainer for the community to fund.
f6_assessments.q1: There are no team more willing and better to do this job than dcSpark. Both Seb and Rob are Cardano OG builders since their Emurgo days who have proven themselves in the ecosystem and delivered a lot of meaningful works and products to the community. They have a sound and deep understanding regarding Cardano infrastructure and how it works. Too bad we are missing some details on the budget breakdown and the estimated completion time. Still, I believe they will do this in the shortest amount of time allowed since they will use this library too and maybe some projects they are partnering with. The only risk is wrong implementation of CIP-25 by most NFT projects in Cardano that will not work with this library. This will be mitigated by loosening the format in the future to factor in the mistakes and make those projects supported. All in all, I believe the delivery of this proposal is in the best hand.
f6_assessments.q2: The necessary actions are divided into five, clear steps. Progress can easily be monitored in the given Github link which is open for anyone to access. Success is explicitly described as the release of the proposed library and being integrated into other tools such CARP and OURA. I think it is as clear as necessary. We can think the implementation of this proposal as public facility works that is essential and the whole member of Cardano community will directly or indirectly enjoy its benefit. Thanks to dcSpark team for always having our back!

f6_assessments.q0: The cip25 (NFT) Rust & WASM library proposal is to create a native Rust, WASM and transcript library that parse CIP25 from CBOR (based on its CDDL specification). The solution will help Rust project users such as Oura, Carp, CSL and CML to avoid subtle error on CBOR parsing. The proposed library can be used from WASM and Typescript as well. This CIP-25 libary proposal effectively address the challenge as it will make it easier to write Dev tool in Rust, WASM and Typescript that need to use CIP25 standard.  The developers can focus on building successful project without worrying bugs from adhoc implementation of CIP25 which is usually the case for NFT projects. For scaling in future challenge, the team might need to loosen the format to accommodate these projects.
f6_assessments.q1: A detailed technical plan is provided in the proposal. The total budget requested for this challenge is sensible at $7000. the team is comprised of Sebastian Guillemot which is a well known developer and another team member with GitHub handle. This adds to project feasibility that it can be completed at ease. It will be helpful for the community if the proposer could pinpoint timeline so that least we all could look out for this CIP-25 library as many of us are involved with NFT projects and look forward to using the library. The team for this mission won't return to Catalyst for funding unless there is a large break change to CIP25 that require a significant rewrote of library. It is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: As mentioned in the feasibilty part that the timeline is needed for the community to audit and track the project progress and completion. The implementation is very much looking forward to by the community and although there is no budget breakdown or other extra information on pay rate etc., it would be really helpful to know when this implementation will take place. Of course, we will check on GitHub but any communication via twitter would also be the alternative way to alert the community that the cip-25 library in RUST & WASM library is ready for use.  The technical roadmap is very clear and the team has clear understandable description of the need for this type of library and propose the solution to help in parsing the on-chain metadata which will be very useful for NFT project developers.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a really useful piece of tooling for the Cardano developer ecosystem that achieves a significant improvement of the current solution and potentially much higher deployment speed. This is exactly what the brief of this Challenge Setting states, so it is 5 out of 5 stars as Rust solutions are definitely not niche and NFT-specific projects are likely to increase. Given the modest 7k budget this seems imminently useful and Sebastian and Rob (or rooooooooob?) are well-known and highly respected contributors for Cardano/dcSpark/Emurgo.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Github profiles of Sebastian and rooooooooob are provided and the track record of the proposers is impressive. The timeline makes sense and the budget is well worth the benefits of the promised library. The project would first update the cddl-codgen to support cNFT compatibility under CIP-25 and then provide the core serialization logic from the cddl definition. Finally, utility functions will be added and the library published as open source. The project would be called a success if it can be integrated by
Oura, Carp, CSL and CML. This "does exactly what it says on the tin" and is a bull's eye for feasibility of successful delivery. I will argue in the Auditability section that a timeline should have provided, and this applies to Feasibility as well, but as we have become used to on-time delivery from the team, this is not considered a problem for the likelihood of success.
f6_assessments.q2:
I wish this proposal has some kind of timeline and would provide a little bit more wording than the budget and successful release as its goal. I have been convinced by the problem-solution statement that this is a useful bit of tooling, and it will be provided by serial contributors whom the community holds in the highest regard. However, some form of acknowledgement of the required format and desire of the community to follow and assess these proposals would have been terrific. 
The 5 milestones are sufficiently clear and in chronological order, so this is far from being a "blank cheque" request, and formal requirements for auditability have been met.

f6_assessments.q0: Your proposed solution seems not to be introduced really clearly. Your project requires more detail of how it works along with the good impacts on the target audience (you had better indicate these subjects directly for the voters to easily know). Second, your key metrics are expressed explicitly and significantly suitable for the challenge. As mentioned earlier, this library will make it easier to write dev tools in Rust, WASM-compatible languages and Typescript that need to consume the CIP25 standard. And this means the project will make it easier for developers to build on top of Cardano to a certain extent. But if you can supplement more detail as well as results that fit the challenge, it would be much better. Actually, I understand the risk that the library can encounter in the future, but not the solution. After reading carefully over and over again, I still have no idea about your exact solution to address the matter: “This library won't be able to parse these projects properly.” Can you elucidate the statement: “Future work may be required to loosen the format to allow for these projects to be supported” since this is quite unintelligible and I’m afraid that the voters may not understand it like me.
f6_assessments.q1: In short, the whole Feasibility section of your proposal doesn’t meet the requirements of the request. There is no part written in detail, to be frank. The first case is your work plan. It contains key milestones, yes I don’t deny that, but even without a single timeline. Even worse, your requested money breakdown doesn’t note any costs for activities which are vital to conduct the project. At least you should enumerate the estimated expenses for your given milestones. The final issue is related to your details of the people who will work on the project. It goes without saying that I and the community have no idea about your team members. Who are they? WHat can they do for the project? And why? Answer these questions and put them in detail for the voters to acknowledge. I believe that if you keep this proposal sketchy like this, the number of downvotes for your project will rise quickly, beyond question.
f6_assessments.q2: For the criterias of success, I don’t have much information to know exactly when your project will succeed. For you, the project comes off when delivering successfully and integrating into other tools. Yet the key point is you don’t explain anything about this “statement”. What are these other tools? At least you should take some examples for the voters to figure out. Or how many tools will your project incorporate? Take a certain number for more transparency. Simultaneously, your measurement part doesn’t meet the standard. No particular measuring tools are mentioned in this proposal, even neither are need-to-be-measured factors. Your given information is so general that the voters can’t be aware of how they can track your project’s progress. Please add extra detail to these problems.

solution: We will create a native Rust, WASM and Typescript library that parses CIP25 from CBOR based on its CDDL specification given in CIP25
experience: Our team consists of the creations of many Cardano Rust efforts used by most Cardano projects including CSL, CML and cddl-codegen.
